# Task

You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.



# Special Instructions

None.

Here is how you can solve this problem:

```julia
using DataFrames, CategoricalArrays
function audi_filter(df_cars)
    df = filter((row) -> row.manufacturer == "audi" && (row.model in ["a4", "a4 quattro"]), df_cars)
    for i in eachindex(df.manufacturer)
        if df.manufacturer[i] == "audi" && (df.model[i] in ["a4", "a4 quattro"])
            df.audi_a4_type = [true] # this creates a new column of true values for each row satisfying the filter conditions
        end
    end
    return df
end
```
This function filters down `df_cars` to only include rows where manufacturer is "audi" and model is either "a4" or "a4 quattro". It then creates a new column `audi_a4_type` of true values. This new DataFrame (`df`) will have the same number of rows as the original DataFrame, but with additional columns (the new `audi_a4_type` column).

Make sure to run the code in your Julia environment and test it on a subset of your actual data before applying it globally. This is to ensure that the function works as expected.
